title: The Impact of Thermal Variability on Aquifer Drawdown: Analyzing the Causal Link
abstract: This study investigates the extent to which variations in thermal conditions influence the rate of aquifer depletion. Recent debates in hydrological science have pointed towards extrinsic environmental factors as potential drivers of groundwater level declines, yet the specific contribution of temperature changes has remained underexplored. Using a multi-decadal dataset, this research employs robust statistical models and hydrological simulations to discern the causal relationship between significant temperature fluctuations and the observed rates of groundwater depletion across several major aquifers. Results indicate a clear and measurable impact of increased temperature variability on the acceleration of groundwater withdrawal rates, primarily through increased evaporative demand and altered precipitation patterns. This study not only delineates the mechanisms through which temperature fluctuations can exacerbate aquifer depletion but also underscores the need for integrating climate variability into groundwater management and sustainability strategies.
